hints_html: Write out the integral definitions of the Laplace transform of \(1\) and \(u(t)\).
hints_latex:
Write out the integral definitions of the Laplace transform of $1$ and
$u(t)$.
hints_raw: Write out the integral definitions of the Laplace transform of <math>1</math> and <math>u(t)</math>.
question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
The Laplace transform only considers positive values of t. Since the heaviside function is identically equal to \(1\) for \(t>0\). That is,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}(1) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} dt = \mathcal{L}(u(t)) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} dt\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The Laplace transform only considers positive values of ''t''. Since the heaviside function is identically equal to <math>1</math> for <math>t>0</math>. That is, 

:<math>\mathcal{L}(1) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} dt = \mathcal{L}(u(t)) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} dt</math>
statement_html: Why are the Laplace transforms of \(1\) and \(u(t)\) (the Heaviside step function) identical?
statement_latex:
Why are the Laplace transforms of $1$ and $u(t)$ (the Heaviside step
function) identical?
statement_raw: Why are the Laplace transforms of <math>1</math> and <math>u(t)</math> (the Heaviside step function) identical?
